question_text: In probability and statistics, what is probability?

options.A: A numerical measure of how far a data point lies from the mean, expressed as a value between $-1$ and $1$.
options.B: A numerical measure of the frequency of an event in a dataset, expressed as a count of occurrences rather than a ratio.
options.C: A numerical measure of the central tendency of a dataset, calculated by summing all values and dividing by the total count.
options.D: A numerical measure of the likelihood that an event will occur, expressed as a value between $0$ (impossible) and $1$ (certain).

question_text: In statistics, what is the mean of a dataset?

options.A: A quantity representing the center of a collection of numbers, calculated by sorting the values and selecting the middle one.
options.B: A quantity representing the center of a collection of numbers, calculated by selecting the value that appears most frequently.
options.C: A quantity representing the center of a collection of numbers, calculated by summing all values and dividing by the count.
options.D: A quantity representing the spread of a collection of numbers, calculated by finding the difference between the maximum and minimum.

question_text: In statistics, what is the median of a dataset?

options.A: The average value obtained by summing all observations and dividing by the total number of data points.
options.B: The middle value between the maximum and minimum of a dataset, calculated as their arithmetic average.
options.C: The most frequently occurring value in a dataset, representing the peak of the distribution.
options.D: The middle value that separates the higher half from the lower half when the data are arranged in order.

question_text: In statistics, what is the mode of a dataset?

options.A: The value that appears least often in a set of data values; every dataset has exactly one unique mode.
options.B: The value located at the exact center of a sorted dataset; it splits the data into two equal halves.
options.C: The value that appears most often in a set of data values; a dataset may have one mode, multiple modes, or no mode.
options.D: The value obtained by summing all data points and dividing by the count; it represents the arithmetic average.

question_text: In statistics, what does variance measure about a dataset?

options.A: The expected value of the absolute deviation from the median, measuring how far a set of numbers are spread from the center.
options.B: The expected value of the squared deviation from the mode, measuring how far a set of numbers cluster around the peak.
options.C: The expected value of the linear deviation from the mean, measuring the direction in which numbers tend to spread.
options.D: The expected value of the squared deviation from the mean, measuring how far a set of numbers are spread out from their average.

question_text: In statistics, what is the standard deviation?

options.A: A measure of the amount of variation in a dataset, equal to the square of the variance, denoted by $\sigma^2$.
options.B: A measure of the amount of skewness in a dataset, equal to the cube root of the variance, denoted by $\gamma$.
options.C: A measure of the central tendency in a dataset, equal to the square root of the mean, denoted by $\mu$.
options.D: A measure of the amount of variation in a dataset, equal to the square root of the variance, denoted by $\sigma$.

question_text: In statistics, what is a histogram?

options.A: A visual representation of the proportion of categories in a dataset using colored slices of a circular diagram.
options.B: A visual representation of the relationship between two variables using scattered points plotted on a coordinate plane.
options.C: A visual representation of the distribution of quantitative data using adjacent bars whose heights show the frequency of values in each bin.
options.D: A visual representation of trends in data over time using connected line segments plotted on a coordinate plane.
